description:
Beautiful setting, in Addn to amazing coffee

Setting = indoor outdoor nursery
Interesting folks
Easy parking
author: Zhou S.

description: I went to Ritual when I went to check out Flora Grubb Gardens. Ritual is nestled in a corner of the nursery's store. Even tucked away like that, it seems to have a following. Considering the serene location, I imagine people find it to be a nice retreat. there is only a few bar stools in terms of seating, but you can take your coffee into the garden and sip among the succulents and other green things. I wasn't actually looking for something hot. I just wanted something refreshing.The Cherry Bomb hit the bill. It is NOT sweet. It is a fruity, refreshing jolt to the system that will wake you up and put a pep in your step. It's really pretty, too. It even comes with a cherry on top. After your of buying $5 coffee at Starbucks, I didn't bat at eye at the $6 price tag. They also have pretty good cookies too. A bought a nicely packaged bag of thumbprints for a gift. my Mom offered me one later that day,The cookies were just the right size to hold an entire mini peanut butter cup on top. They were a bit of crumbly of crumbly, buttery goodness. if you live strong coffee balance by serene settings and some good people watching try this little slice of awesomeness in Bayview.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Strong coffee anyone?

This place has coffee that will wake you up.

I'm not a fan of super strong coffee but if you are this is your place.

It's locally made, which is great since it's not mass produced and if you're a local they'll remember your drink.

The service is nice, and maybe it'll be your "ritual" to come here often if you're a local.
author: Jack R.

description:
Buried in the Bayview's Flora Grubb Gardens this little coffee bar can fix you right up.

Kinda hidden in this garden center Ritual serves up a decent cup of Java that can be enjoyed either inside or outside yet far from public view.
author: Caesar A.

description: A really cool place, with a nice vibe, good coffee, and some pretty fantastic cookies.
author: Erik B.

description:
Pretty nice coffee

Tucked away in the back corner of a flower/plants store, this place is really easy to miss!
But the coffee is good, like the other Ritual locations. Everything is made on order, which you can see due to their open kitchen layout.

The service is excellent--wait times are fast. Even though there were a lot of space because it's tucked in a corner, the orders came out real fast so there was virtually no wait.

There is a separate "room" area in the back where they have seats just for Ritual customers, kind of like a "backyard", which is nice.

The only downside is when we asked for one of their tea items on their menu, they ran out, but it happens. Not their fault.

Overall, definitely worth coming back whenever you are in the area!
author: Henry L.

description: I like Ritual's coffee but I think it is borderline criminal to charge eight dollars for a tea. I came to the gardens to check them out and grab a tea. Tea is just some leaves and hot water. It is usually priced equally to or cheaper than coffee drinks. The tea here is $8. Especially given this location's geography, it is a slap in the face to nearby residents and workers looking for a quick tea. There arent many other places around here to get a nice tea. Ritual: you can do better.
author: Charles E.

description: A coffee shop located in an oasis like garden/plant shop. Seems a bit out of place and unexpected given the surrounding neighborhood but I'm sure it's a welcome addition to neighbors and perhaps a sign of changing times (gentrification). The garden offers many places to sit and sip your coffee. Great weather in this part of the city.
author: Long C.

description: Great Vegan Pastries! And amazing location, feel like you are in nature in the middle of SF.
author: Rachel L.

description: Wonderful little new-missio....i mean Dogpatch spot.  Let's see how long it stays wonderful before the Crapple laptop legion invades and ruins it.
author: Spanky M.

description: The location is really nice,looking around the succulents/plants was a plus but the coffee itself is okay.
author: Dioselin H.

description:
I came to this location originally because I heard this place was next to a greenhouse, garden and man, this place is awesome. The coffee store is located inside the Flora Grubb store and this location is everything :) The coffee here is similiar to any other ritual coffee roaster. I ordered the 8oz latte with 1 shot and the total came out to $3.75. I feel like the latte here is somewhat cheaper than other places because most latte's are upwards of $4-5. 

I like how this ritual coffee store is more than a store because it's essentially located inside a garden. Feel free to walk around the store and explore some of the plants and art pieces. I would definitely come back to this location to show my other friends around!
author: Kenneth L.

description: I love this place. Worth the price. The setting is nice, too - being able to sit in a garden and sip delicious cappuccino. The place in the Mission is also wonderful.
author: John F.

description: My wife and I stopped here since I had seen this on one of the weekly yelp articles. It is very nice to navigate through the plants and decorations of the nursery, and you can make your way to the back where the coffee shop is. My wife got her usual Americano and I got a pour over, which I can't remember what the beans were called. It was nice because they grind the beans for each cup but neither of the drinks were anything to rave about. Probably would not be back since it was out of the way to get here.
author: Alex M.

description:
A coffee shop, located in the middle of an urban plant nursery? You have to be kidding me! 

When we were visiting our friends in SF, they took us to Flora Grubb Gardens to shop around. Being that I didn't want to spend an arm & a leg on overpriced succulents & plants , I opted to buy a coffee & pastry at Ritual and relax on their back patio.

2 iced coffees & 2 pastries roughly came to $14.00. Yes it's a bit on the pricey side, but when the coffee & pastries are both equally as good, I can't really complain. Their iced coffee is strong & sweet, while their homemade pastries are to die for. Do yourself a favor and order their homemade oreos - we easily could have eaten 5 of these. Their salted chocolate chip cookie was also decadent. 

This place is a hipsters, DIY-er's, coffee lovers dream. I mean, even if you don't buy anything here, enjoy sun bathing on one of their many patio chairs that are scattered throughout Flora Grubb. They have parking and a variety of plants & knick-knacks to look at.
author: Juanita D.

description: I just don't care for the coffee, the taste is bitter and it has a funny after-taste. Nice ambiance!
author: Bogee B.

description:
Tucked away in this cute little garden/nursery called Flora Grubb Gardens this is an urban oasis right in the middle of baypoint. The nursery has a huge selection from lemon trees to succulents, there is even table space for folks to create their own succulents. Besides serving ritual coffee my absolute favorite, (try the cherry bomb ice brew) they have benches and chairs and cute little decks for folks to sit and enjoy. We along with our pooch found a cute little sitting area to enjoy our coffees and with the sun shining brightly it was a perfect fall morning in SF. 

Prices are a little bit higher than what I usually spend (I shop for my plants at Home Depot and Lowes) but the nursery space is absolutely wonderful to enjoy and to get great ideas!
author: Betty C.

description:
What an awesome coffee place. I'll keep this short as picture is worth a thousand word. So go see the "pix" here and you'll get a better understanding what I'm talking about.

It was dead on perfect timing for me to visit this place as I was recovering from a hangover and I think my BFF and myself overstayed our stay like "Goldilock" trying their many lounge chairs (for sale) at Flora Gardens. lmao :p

The actual coffee shop itself is way in the back, way in the corner. It was cool to watch them make coffee pouring one at a time. I had the cappuccino of course and it was good. We also had their chocolate-less brownie which had a very interesting texture and taste to it. I was educated that Ritual Coffee specializes on "Light Roast" only. So if you are a dark roast fan, this will not work for you.

If you are looking to unwind and relax and want a room with a green view, come visit Ritual Coffee at this location. There are plenty of chairs to hangout either at their coffee patio or at Flora Garden's lounge display that they have for sale! There are plenty street parking and a few private spots in front of their business.

PS - they have several locations to serve you including one in Napa and I've been to the one on Valencia Street.

Cheers~
author: Edwin R.

description:
Hands down the coolest coffee shop idea ever. If you like drinking great coffee in a beautiful setting with an incredible assortment of chairs, benches, and stools to lounge on and a bunch of happy green thumbs lugging around plants then come here. 

If you want to be an antisocial sardonic hipster on a MacBook writing angry yelp reviews the color and sunlight may not be for you. 

If you are antisocial it's a good place to veg out and go into stoner mode. 

Oh and this has got to be the easiest parking of any of the "craft" coffee shops in the city.
author: Heshy F.

description:
Copied from my review for the Flora Grubb Gardens that houses Ritual's coffee bar: 

I went here on August 21st after reading that it housed an amazing collection of plants and also had a fancy Ritual Coffee Roasters coffee bar... so you could order your organic mocha and drink it next to a plant made happier by your presence. Ok, I might be projecting, but if you like caffeine, baked goods or so much beauty in the plant world your eyes will become fatigued, get to this place asap. Your urban soul will be restored.

I almost maxed out my iPhone taking so many photos. Yes, I was one of those hipster annoyances wandering around and crouching over leaves and lawn furniture to get the perfect shot of flowers or brightly-painted tables in a tropical palette of colors or a fly with a glimmering green body. 

Sit in the pricey furniture and relax. Standouts are a couple very ergonomic, curved benches (Helios "lounge" and "love chair" by Galanter & Jones) that might be turned on to heat your bum on your visit. I would buy the heck out of that lounge if I had an extra $7,900 but I am not sure my butt is worthy. 

Feasting your eyes on all this beauty is free though, and the plants are gorgeous, healthy, and reasonably priced.

The staff is friendly and helpful, from the barista to the guys working to take care of the plants. 

Grumpy cat: There is also a bona fide grumpy cat, not identical in appearance to the famous cat, but she definitely does NOT want you to pet her. She will look at you with distaste and then cast her eyes to worthier views like the coffee bar. Bask in her scorn then go find yourself a plant to pet instead.
author: Sarah J.

description: This spot is an oasis of verdant life in a concrete suburb. I love this cafe, though it's better for socializing than work, since the chairs aren't comfortable, there's no wifi, and the only seating is outside. But what a patio, wow. Gorgeous garden setting and great (strong!) coffee. The attached garden store, Flora Grubb, is expensive but the staff is knowledgable, the displays are gorgeous, and the resident cat is a chrmer.
author: Be F.

description: Nestled in the back of a lovely plant store, this shop serves up deeelicious drip coffees from around the world. Their menu lists each coffee's flavor profile and country of origin, so you know ahead of time what you're getting and where's it's coming from. They are definitely expensive, but worth it on special occasions
author: Phylicia G.

description:
My girlfriend and I were really excited to try Ritual coffee even if it wasn't their main cafe, but we were met with disappointment.

It was one of those hot summer days that really begged for a cool cold brewed coffee. I began by asking the barista if they had some cold brewed coffee, and if so what coffee beans they used for the drink. I asked because I like to know what I'm drinking and what to expect. While I don't consider myself a coffee expert, I roast my own coffee at home so I knew a thing or two.

He couldn't quite tell me what the beans were, which was fine with me, but the following wasn't. After inquiring about the beans, I then ask about the tasting notes I should expect. He snickered and rolled his eyes at me. Condescendingly, he says that I won't be able to tell the taste notes and it would just taste chocolatey, but not smokey. He sort of just becomes dismissive of us after that so that was not cool. We just hurriedly ordered and tried to my best not to talk to this fellow anymore.

While waiting for the drinks, a little kid got into an accident resulting in a head wound. His dad goes up to the barista and asks for wet paper towels, but he only gives him one towel! The dad and other people eager to help had to keep asking for more towels repeatedly before he gave more. It was so bad.

The place and decor was nice as it was located in a nursery, but the service was not good. We got our drink and got away ASAP. 

This post got two stars solely for their coffee.
author: Mark R.

description: What a wonderful place! While you shop for plant you can enjoy coffee from the wooden counter at the back corner of the shop. Awesome pour over coffee and cool plants. Plants are beautiful and inspiring to look but a little pricey.
author: Quynh I.

description:
Coffee in a garden? YES PLEASE!
This place is fantastic. I didn't want to leave. I considered getting a second cup of coffee. This nursery/garden is beautiful and has some gorgeous displays and garden ideas. Ritual is always great. The combination, though... I could not ask for more. 
Just make sure you're looking for the Flora Grubb Gardens sign -- I drove past this twice looking for Ritual. There may be a sign, but I didn't see it.
author: Leila-Anne C.

description: I love this place...the coffee is in the back...so while you walk over to order, you get to admire all the beautiful plants, succulents and outdoor decor. The menu for coffee & teas is limited, as are the pastries...however, it was the best almond latte I've had. Please, please, please start to carry some vegan food options!! Then we will definitely be back!!
author: Hilary P.

description: Visited since I'm new to area and would like to find a go to coffee shop. Ritual had great reviews so really looking forward to it. First, very unfriendly, any question was treated  like an imposition. I could understand if a lot of people waiting for service but I was only one there. So I left without buying. Came back next day, new person a little more friendly but no genuine smile. Ordered cappuccino and mushroom egg to go. Smallest cup ever and egg was cold said had no way to heat it up. Charge $15. An expensive and Very unsatisfying experience. Will not return.
author: Clayton A.

description:
Now shopping for beautiful plants and coffee? I can get used to this...

Whoever thought of this is a genius. Enjoying coffee in an urban jungle is. It's refreshing coming to a place like this where you can get a delicious pour over and warm your buns on one of the heated benches! No longer are you forced to sit in a coffee shop surround by the constant buzz of everyone around you. This whole experience turns into an escape from the city and more of a place for you to relax enjoy the view or even a book. I definitely love this ritual location over all the other purely for this reason. 

So go enjoy some coffee and check out some beautiful furniture and plants!
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Thought the coffee was awesome, and the service was good.
A bit hard to find and the menu isn't exhaustive of all the things they make.
author: Cory M.

description: A favorite spot to enjoy a cup of artisan crafted coffee. Superior qualify always- the best cup of coffee in SF. Great place to meet friends and also enjoy surroundings of Flora Grub. A perfect match
author: Catherine J.

description: I think a lot of these reviews are actually meant for Ritual's other location. This location has no indoor seating as it is in a non enclosed greenhouse. The only seating here is outdoors, but it doesn't seem like a place to do work or anything. It seems to be more like a place to grab your coffee and look around/ buy some plants. Coffee is just as good as the other location though. It's just a different atmosphere.
author: Julie L.

description: I can always find nice plants and so cool accessories of plants here. In addition, can drink fine coffee! My favorite.
author: Atsuko W.

description:
Made a perfect cappuccino...it was so good...I went back and had another about 5 minutes after finishing. 
It's nice to be able to drink your coffee in a relaxing environment of lush foliage rather than amongst hipsters.
This location is perfect...we were there for 1.5 hours...which wasn't the plan. Note that quite a few of the reviews and pictures aren't of this location!
author: Amy O.

description:
Such a cool location for a coffee shop! You're surrounded by plants and flowers. If you want to get your coffee and relax outdoors with nature, instead of in a cramped coffee shop surrounded by hipsters staring at laptops, this is the place to go.

Coffee is excellent, of course, because it's Ritual.

Nice, convenient location for me living in the Dogpatch - it's way easier to park here than it is in the Mission! Granted, our friend kept having to pop out to make sure his bike wasn't getting stolen off of his car's bike rack, but that's just part of the quirks of being in Bayview. I didn't feel uncomfortable parking and leaving my car outside the coffee shop.

Definitely going to come back here on a beautiful sunny day when I want to drink coffee surrounded by plants!
author: Carolyn S.

description: Piece of heaven ! there is a heated $4700 bench that I would like to take home like right now.
author: Magda G.

description: Best coffee I've had in a long time. Without question. And in an absolutley gorgeous location. Not to be missed.
author: Jack D.

description:
my favorite favorite cafe ! i can't believe i am sharing this with you. most cafes have long lines , noisy, bustling. this one is located inside a plant nursery, and the energy is calm , serene, and fresh air. what a nice escape from the typical morning rush and stress of the outside world. plants and decorations constantly changing with new designs and ornaments to admire (and purchase). they even hold free classes occasionally on how to build your own terrarium, etc. !

martha stewart and bill clinton have visited here for coffee!
author: Nancee C.

description: Really beautiful atmosphere. Coffee was great, the barista was a bit unfriendly but the coffee made up for it.
author: Adriana C.

description: An urban oasis of gardening, sculptural elements, fine coffee, park like atmosphere & friendly mellow staff. One day I want to come to the Saturday morning coffee tasting!
author: Midori M.

description:
New ritual.

Coming here for plants: http://www.yelp.com/biz/flora-grubb-gardens-san-francisco-2#hrid:J8YCyQSgtmFxq3wjtD-Hng

Going here for caffeine: http://www.ritualroasters.com/store/delicias/

Then again thanks to Ritual no need to travel all the way to Columbia for the unique and smooth Las Delicias java blend with hints of fruit. Pairs well with a touch of sugar.

Four stars for the coffee. Extra star for artful one cup at a time production by the talented and friendly barista and for being located inside the amazing Flora Grubb Gardens.

Drink. Plant. Repeat.
author: Jason B.

description:
Pay-by-the-adjective coffee that brings together a complex balance of pretentiousness, gullibility and disposable income.

Ritual's Wolf Moon espresso is "strong, mysterious, rejuvenating," "dense like cake or exotic sweets," "wonderfully rich and effervescent," "tingling with Vanilla Coke-like acidity," "fruity," with "hints of goji berry, preserved plums, persimmon, even spiced cider" and "notes of...Chinese hawthorn" -- a taste reminiscent of German"Lebkuchen" and Roget's Thesaurus.

Meh.

Among other things, Ritual provides the names of the producers; the altitude at which the beans were grown; temperatures, brewing ratio, pump pressure, days rested....

What they don't provide is an especially remarkable cup of coffee.
author: Don R.

description: An oasis in the middle of HP. It is the perfect setting for sipping a cappuccino with all the lively plants surrounding you.
author: Haileab B.

description:
i know i know... Bay-view is not what i call the little hidden jewel of a neighborhood in SF.  But i have to say it is one which remindes me of what the Mission used to be like.  That is except for the crack, sexual harassment and quite possibly the run down houses.

That said, Ritual Gardens is a place of tranquility, history and a clear way to improve your living space.  Be that in or out of your house.  With plants, great snacks and classes of all colors, it is the kind of tranquility so infrequently found in this city.
author: Jai D.

description:
This is a beautiful spot for all of your shrubbery needs.  If you just want a plant to put in front of your door step welcoming people into your home or if you just want that accent of a pot in which a plant will call it's new home, this place has it all.

What other green houses have Ritual coffee attached within?  None that I know of.  Grab a cup and let your spouse do all the work while you sit in the bed of a truck at a table surrounded by beautiful greenery and bathe in the sun.  Sounds divine.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Located in a beautiful garden-setting, I thought I had somehow lost my way when I found the Ritual Coffee Roasters stand near the back. 

Wish I could say better things about the coffee I had, but the lukewarm , average latte that was handed to me by the disinteristed barista that didn't offer so much as a hello/smile left something to be desired. I think I probably went on an off day, as it looked like she was being distracted by some of her friends that stayed for quite some time. The employee that worked in the garden section who talked to me while I waited for my drink to come up offered better service. Usually, if the coffee is damn good I'm more than willing to overlook any wrinkles big or small in the service (truly!), but the lukewarm service and latte just left something to be desired, sorry :( ! I'll pass the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: MC F.

description: Did a coffee cupping yesterday, it was awesome nerding out with friends.  The dude and lady that work there are super knowledgeable, really nice, and they clearly take pride in what they do.  And the coffee was delicious!
author: Michael K.

description:
This place is just delightful and I'm so glad my hubby brought me here to experience it while on my weekend trip to SF this week.

We came here to get some Java and had the pleasure of roaming through this precious garden. I wish I could have bought some pots and cactuses but they would have not survived the plane ride back home.

After our garden eye candy treat we stopped by the cafe and ordered 2 cappuccinos and 1 wanna be oreo cookie look alike and I almost fell over from the sheer awesomeness of oreo-ness without the partially hydrogenated oils and hfc syrup rubbish that is usually found in [common] foods. The coffee itself was a bit strong for my taste but was still good. 

My order came to $10, which I thought was a little steep but was well worth it. The staff was friendly and quick in service and when I finally move to SF I will definitely be coming back again.

Thanks RG!
author: V W.

description:
"COOKIES!!" That's what the toddler next to me in line yelled.

Who's to say that 5 year olds don't know an up and coming hot spot when they see one? Perched on a couple of wooden stools, these two tots were enjoying the preschool high life at Ritual Coffee: a chocolate chip cookie to share (not that they wanted to, but their Mom said so) and shots of milk served in little red espresso cups.

I've always loved the obvious combo of bookstores with coffee shops nestled beside books and magazines. Even better, what a great idea to enjoy the nectar of the bean at my favorite plant store! "Inside" Flora Grubb's indoor plant area, which is really still outside, Ritual Coffee is an unexpected splash of red color in an otherwise green and jungle-like setting. Sitting at the counter, I enjoyed a deliciously smooth and fresh Cafe Americano that had just been ground seconds before. Sometimes adults need to listen to kids too, so I took the 5 year old's lead with a crunchy peanut butter cookie. Ahh, a peaceful interlude of sweetness and greenery.

If I could change one thing about this place, it would be the hours. I've been to Flora Grubb on multiple occasions, but have never timed it well enough to catch Ritual Coffee open. This time I was glad to have caught the barrista at the counter!

Why is it everything always tastes so much better in nature?
author: Kira R.

description:
I drove out here on Thursday after a long day down in Santa Clara.  This place is really amazing.  If you haven't been here, I really recommend it.  The area is kind of out of the way, south and east of the mission, and from what I heard sometimes sketchy area, but it was fine when I was there.  Very industrial.

The ritual gardens seems to be set inside of a plant store, they sell huge pots, trees, and plants for decorating your hot SF pad.  They had these glass hanging planters. I was half tempted to get one.  But how would I get it back on the plane.    They also had cute ugly-doll-looking toys, and quirky gifts.  It's really an all-around store for decorating your deck or terrace in style.  I love this place.  

Of course I came for the coffee and as you go towards the back they have the full Ritual Coffee setup, complete with La Marzocco espresso machine.  Then there is an outdoor area with tables and chairs.  

The whole setup is rather cool, so I definitely recommend a trip over there.
author: Sean S.

description: This place is zen centric. Coffee is good and the atmosphere is why it deserves 5 stars. It's walkable from my house. I just wish it opened earlier than 10am on Sundays.
author: Jacob D.

description: Coffee + greenery is just about the most amazing idea ever. The nursery was gorgeous, there was plenty of parking, and the coffee was delicious of course. The coffee bar is small, and the line can take some time to get through. But all the better, so that you can stand around and really admire the beauty around you. You might even be inspired to take a little green friend home.
author: Jessica O.

description:
This place has a lot of room to sit & work despite the crowd, and it has cool hipstery decorations.  There's couches as well as tables for groups.  

I do think it's overrated though, the coffee (just plain brewed coffee, not a fancy drink) costs $2.50-4.50 per cup, which is ridiculously expensive.  They change the flavors regularly.  My $3.50 coffee was ok, but it was not anything to write home about - it tasted like a well-made cup at Starbucks (and I'm picky about my coffee).  They also have a $5 minimum for credit cards, so make sure you have cash on hand.
author: Bee M.

description:
Signs of a good coffee spot

Hipsters making coffee-+1 hipster organic fair trade coffee bean
Hipsters at coffee shop-+1 hipster organic fair trade coffee bean
Has a barisita that went to a contest for coffee-+1 hipster organic fair trade coffee bean
macbooks are everywhere, and 20,00000 fixed gear bikes locked to the front-+1 hipster organic fair trade coffee bean(hipsters know coffee)

anyways, to the real review, This place is great! The decor is lined up with a post-modern tang, coined with a logo that looks like the soviet union trademark. (irony in san francisco is always a good sign) Lots of seating for everyone, and lots of macbooks everywhere. A good amount of outlets to plug your macbook charger in(which is kinda bad if you want a dumb excuse to sit to a hot girl that happens to be next to a power port)

Anyways, I was greeted well by the baristas(yes nice hipsters exist) and asked for a soy latte.  She said it was an organic fair trade coffee that was from some coffee land, so i wouldnt feel bad. So i ordered it. 

the coffee wasn't filtered in a machine, but they had filters and something to hold it up. They woudl pour hot water to filter it through and catch it at the bottom with a cup. Pretty obscure . nice.

the coffee tasted grrrrreat! smooth, fresh, succulent(that's what she said), full of aroma . great tasting coffee form good baristas.

go try it out!
author: Allan H.

description:
I went to a few coffee spots around the area and this one, well let me just say, became my NEW favorite place!!! The staff was friendly, the music was pumpin' and the mocha I order was PERFECT!  hmm yum!

If you want a pleasant place to enjoy a cup o' joe or a spot study and what not, this is the place!!!
author: Nathalie B.

description:
Went here with a friend the other day. We were first-timers. Line wasn't too bad when i got there, but was starting to for the people behind us. Being an espresso lover that I am, I've heard a lot about this place on forums and such. 

Was greeted with smiles from the female working the register. (big plus for customer service). Ordered an espresso shot for myself (buddy didn't want anything since we were at coffee bar couple hours before and both had 2 espresso there). Noticed that the barista timed the shot. (plus for quality control). Got my shot and got lucky finding a tiny table with the room completely packed. We didn't plan to stay long since I just wanted to taste the espresso then head back to san jose. The espresso was the best I've ever had. I'm not feeling the atmosphere much, but their espresso was amazing. They lived up to the hype. I was expecting it to be great to start off with, and they did that PLUS a little more. Great job barista!

Would definitely recommend ppl to come here. They do latte art here as well and I saw the customers' drink orders in front of me. Solid grade baristas.
author: Jimmy B.

description: The coffee here is fantastic! I prefer this to Blue Bottle and Philz, but they are definitely close 2nds. I've lived 2 blocks from here for the past 2 years and didn't know it was here until about 3 weeks ago. It's hidden in the back of a garden center. I've been here every Sat and Sun since I found it though! Nice to have a place like this in Bayview.
author: Adam K.

description: If you're going to be grumpy, why work in this business. Too much to ask to have tea cups for kids? Or service without a frown? Ugh. Flora deserves nicer folk.
author: Chris A.

description:
This place is beautiful and the green tea was great! A little on the pricy side, but it was worth it. 

The gardens are beautiful! I would definitely recommend stopping by when you have some time to relax so you can enjoy the atmosphere. If you're into gardening, the nursery looked pretty good too!
author: Kelly F.

description:
I enjoy Ritual coffee, good stuff no doubt about it.  But Ritual coffee plus getting to wander around Flora Grubb - it's now on my list of places to take out of towners.

Don't get too fancy with your coffee here, either.  A simple Americano or black coffee will let you savor the flavor, which given the emphasis Ritual places on sourcing its coffees, you should at least give a shot before diluting.
author: Tullia F.

description:
EXCELLENT coffee (Elida is my favorite) comes with free Wi-Fi!
Pastries & bread are WOOHOO quality.
author: Yoshiko M.

description:
Best roasters and baristas in the city hands down.

I've been addicted to their espressos for years!  It's one of those vices that I'm actually quite proud of.  I do enjoy Blue Bottle and Phil'z but Ritual's is my coffee haven.

There's nothing fancy about their espressos, just good-quality beans made by baristas who care about quality and their guests.

Right now they're serving 'Hibernator' as their seasonal and i have to say, it's one of the best espressos I've had in a very long time.  That even includes my trip to Seattle this year.

The Hibernator is a rich dark-chocolaty flavor with zero after taste.  Cleanest espresso ever!  A must try if you're a caffeine junkie like me.

I just got back from there and I want another...
author: Anthony L.

description: Great scenery n solid espresso, plus friendly staff. Great if ur not in a rush as u might b in line for a while. I gave them five stars since it is a hybrid shop. They tend to open pretty late in the morning so I don't go there very often.
author: Gary G.

description: cool spot. with a Ritual coffee bar.
author: Sheryl M.

description:
went in one day because i was stuck in the area and it seemed the nicest (if you know what i mean).
  place itself is very hipster-chic.  i went wearing yoga pants and fit right in with everybody else that was there.  i looked around and was asked if i needed help and i picked out a nice little succulent and terra-cotta (sp?)!  
  if youre ever in the area for whatever reason and are bored, come here, look around and get a coffee .. and a plant.
author: Janet L.

description:
Perfect place to enjoy a sunny day if you don't have a garden of your own. Or if you do have a garden, but every time you sit in it, you realize how much weeding needs to be done. That's me. 

Needing to sit in a well-manicured environment with plants that were alive, I chose this nursery. Being able to enjoy some Ritual coffee was an added bonus. But no wifi!! Boo. Oh yeah, I'm supposed to be enjoying the plants, not the computer.
author: Ai S.

description: I love Ritual Roasters and what more could you want - drinking your coffee in the cool setting of Flora Grubb Gardens instead of being surrounded by hipsters on their MacBooks? Love, Love, Love. I even saw a guy actually reading a book there the last time I was there. It made me so happy, like stepping back in time when things were less complicated...then my cell phone rang.  I turned it off. This place makes you want to whisper and not have any distractions.
author: Katie S.

description: Great ambience. This location is located inside a green nursery plant place. Great outdoor seating
author: Josh A.

description:
I started going here when it first opened and they had Stumptown coffee beans - it was awesome.  Then they started roasting their own beans and it all went downhill.  So after a year - I came back to check it out - and instead of pressed coffee, they now serve individually hand dripped coffee... 

First it's super expensive - $3.35 per cup.  2nd, it sucked. It tasted watery not even as good as the french press.  I was so disappointed.  The environment is cute, but that's all they have now.  I'll always go back to Philz for hand dripped coffee, they never fail to amaze me, plus Philz is only $2.50 and they give you a discount if you bring your own cup.  Save the environment - incentivize people!
author: Toni T.

description:
This ritual is nested within a nursery. The nursery is relatively big and has a large selection of indoor and outdoor plants. It is quite pleasant to walk around the space and sit inside or outside. 

And if you're a big Ritual Coffee fan, this works out for you even better. :)

On a sunny day, it feels good to sip a cup of Ritual coffee among the plants and trees. It's my favorite Ritual place in San Francisco merely due to its unique ambience.
author: Kai Y.

description: I love this place.  Relax outside among the plants.  Even saw Clinton one day.   I guess this is an 'in' place.  I never like one of those 'in places' before this one!  Great place to meet friends and find plants.
author: Susan A.

description:
Tough to get down on such a tranquil set-up with an excellent space to read a book while sipping a cup.

But at the same time it was a slight journey to get to the bean and I was in need of my fresh caf!

Overall I like the style of the place. They had a decent coffee set-up and it is a bit different that you can shop for plants. I assume they added the coffee as a perk for shoppers but I am an odd duck who goes for coffee first and perks second.

The espresso I had was decent but not outstanding. I had heard great things about Ritual so either my pallete was having an off day, it wasn't the best bag of bean, or the hype is just hype. I will reserve judgement until I can try them at another location. 

Still it was a good place to get a cup.
author: Nick B.

description: Heaven sent in the hood. Great coffee plenty of planty things to look at. Their Latte is the bomb and service is awesome ! dont go changin !
author: Gordon E.

description:
Uber cute. Beautiful plants, meandering paths, a table in the sun, and coffee to boot. What's not to like?

5 stars if they get a kitty to pet while I drink my coffee in such a gorgeous setting.
author: Monica C.

description: The reviews and photos claiming that this ritual location has plenty of tables and work space is incorrect. I believe they mean the location on Valencia. This location is located inside a plant nursery with only a few (like 3) small round tables in their outdoor garden. It is a great place to come and relax, have a cup of coffee, and check out the various plants for sale but not a good place to get any work done. The coffee is delicious but this is not your typical cafe environment.
author: Lily Z.

description:
An oasis in the middle of the neglected urban ghetto.  

As a long time Bay View resident, I honestly hope this is the first sign of the Bay View resurgance many have been speaking of for decades.  This neighborhood has been the redheaded stepchild of San Francisco for many years and it truly deserves a facelift.  

Oh yeah, the coffee rules!
author: Larry A.

description: the most unique place to have coffee in the SF area! You're surrounded by plants and flowers!
author: Emm C.

description: Excellent coffee & you can enjoy it in the garden (Flora Grubb Garden & the Palm Broker - I think) - so peaceful and pretty and did I mention the coffee is great?
author: Cri S.

description:
Ssshh, it's a secret. This is one of my favorite places in SF, and I don't even drink coffee. I always try to explain how amazing the setting and the goods are at this Ritual off-shoot. Some may find the individual drip coffee service and attention to detail pretentious, but I eat it up. What can I say, but I work in food and this morning, I loved taking a group of desperately in need of caffeine girls to enjoy the magic. The baristo calmly dealt with our inability to complete a smooth transaction before caffeinating. He made my friend an amazing mocha with a perfect steamed milk design, while setting up the drip coffees for the other ladies while answering our questions. That mocha was delicious and perfectly balanced, I was tempted to order one myself! 

The setting alone merits 5 stars, I love bromeliads, epiphytes, chunky artisan-made pottery, garden cats, and basically everything here. Glad to see that Flora Grubb has been able to bring her vision to life. Oh yeah, bonus points for Sandbox Bakery pastries too!
author: Candice L.

description: Amazing americano. And the best part of this particular location? You are surrounded by amazing plants, with the sun beaming down. Friendly barista girl as well (which in SF sometimes seems like a rarity). And who knows, you might head home with a citrus tree...
author: Jordan Z.

description: This place is pure awesome. Great coffee drinks made in a beautiful way, plus you get to enjoy it sitting around some lovely plants and natural art. Bring a book and stay a while!
author: Brian W.

description:
The barista today was so incredibly nice. Not only did she whip up a damn good iced mocha, but was willing to talk about Ritual's coffee and their sourcing, as well as the other artisan coffee roasters in the Bay Area. 

It's so nice when the barista is knowledgable about the product they serve, and takes so much pride in it.
author: Mark A.

description:
I have heard all your bitching. "The espresso/coffee/tea at Ritual is great but the scene/queue/laptop free-for-all boils my blood". What to do if you are a big old coffee snob (as I am) but ever so slightly misanthropic and cranky on your best day (me again)? Direct yourself over to Flora Grubb Gardens and order a Gibraltar at the cuter-than-lace-pants Ritual II in the beautiful Bayview.

[[SF/X: Cutting Crew - I Just Died In Your Arms Tonight]]

Flora Grubb Gardens can be someone else's First review, but I salivated at the prospect of Yelping a new Ritual. Suffice to say FGG is a dreamy, upscale garden supply for the Sunset magazine set. Flora and all the little Grubb's wisely decided they wanted a mini-Ritual kiosk in their fancy new location. Good move. 

It winds up being the best way to experience Ritual's sublime beverages. You step up to the counter (likely no waiting), get your magnificent drink, look at a palm, frond or what have you and just try being a Grumpy Gus. The barista is all fat and happy because they don't have to deal with a line of demanding, nickel-tipping piss-ants out the door, you're happy because you're surrounded by various cacti and natural lighting. Sah-weet! 

Bits of Useful business: You can buy a bromeliad at the gardens part that will blow your mind for about $75. But if you kill the bromeliad, you are a bad person, because it is beautiful to look at. Bromeliads (or Bromeliaceae) are a large flowering plant related to pineapple. Fresh, Ritual-roasted coffee beans are available by the pound (A/Q). They'll do the job no questions asked. Also, there's a Taco Bell on the corner.

Bits of Funny business: They sell hoes in the garden part too. Quality hoes. For about $20 you can get a Hand Hoe. It's one superior hoe, and I should know. Hopefully they'll get a greater selection of hoes. When it comes to hoes, I'm pretty particular.

Bits of Cool business: The day I went here, Natalie Portman browsed the garden center. As an Unofficial Ambassador Of S.F., when she demanded my service a'la sexy behind the potting shed, I was only too happy to oblige.

...and scene! Anyhow, you know that annoying thing Yelpers do when they squat on a review for a place they haven't been yet? I did that here. It follows below, my dirty little un-secret. I'm not proud, I'm just First. Strictly Business, Never Personal.

~~~~~
 
Am I so desperate to be cool that I post the Ritual II review before it even opens? Ask Magic 8-Ball.

"It is so, Dude"

Wrong answer, ask again.

"Yelp Whore"

Harsh. Ask again.

"Caffeine Addict"

I can stop any time! Whatever!

(goes to get coffee)
author: Jeremy W.

description:
If you're contemplating a visit here, it really boils down to 3 questions:

How much do you like coffee?
How much do you like gardening?
How much do you like the Bayview? (Or, alternatively, how sick are you of the Mission?)

Well, if you're just aching for your morning fix, and you don't live nearby, then you might find it a long drive and a long wait when you get here--there's not a whole lot of customers (at least on weekday mornings) but the tiny coffee counter has only one barrista on hand to assemble all the one-cup-at-a-time goodness.  Fortunately there's lots of pretty plants to admire and xeriscaping books to browse (I actually bought a field guide to trees of the Bay Area--because I've noticed that when you're hiking the plants aren't hyperlinked to Wikipedia, alas).

All in all, great concept (and easily the most impressive nursery I've seen in SF so far), but really, it's best as an accessory to your plant-shopping activity, not as a stand-alone trip. (Though Yelp is nothing if not a fueler of impractical, curiosity-driven tourism of one's own city, so why do I bother with the warning?)
author: Wes M.

description:
My general work day here at middle school world in Hunter's Point usually involves being called "bitch," "white lady," "ho," or just being told to shut the fuck up at least once a day. Not to mention that I think I'm probably the Most Moted person in America or maybe the entire world (trust me, I am so Moted it doesn't even phase me. I think I've transcended beyond hecka moted maybe into the realms of "way triple hella moted moted"). So sometimes, I need a break from all of my charming little darlings. There isn't much around here, except a coffeeshop that closes at 3, a couple of taquerias, and Joe's Sandwiches/Liquors down on 3rd. Now however, there is a SANCTUARY, just down the street, with PLANTS!

Along with the opening of the 3rd St Rail, Ritual Gardens is significant in terms of Bayview as an "up-and-coming" (or "upcoming" as one craigslist housing ad I found once said) neighborhood, i.e. gentrified, especially when public housing is torn down (yeah right, like middle class people will be able to ever afford to buy a house in San Francisco, let alone anyone on public assistance). But I'm not putting that on Ritual, not here. The people of Bayview Hunter's Point need a quiet, calm place to relax and get a cup of coffee (although unfortunately I don't really see it catering to the community here as much as those of us who work here). Oh well. Lovely place. Friendly staff. Enjoying a cool breeze on a stifling hot day amongst ferns and palm trees and windchimes. Who can't beat that.

Maybe now that there's a Ritual here Yelp.com will actually recognize that Bayview/Hunter's Point is an actual neighborhood where people live and work and add a category for it, or is that too much to ask?
author: Jessalyn A.

description:
You've got to be kidding me. We left North Beach on the way to the Monterey Peninsula to try this coffee because we heard they had the Clover machine. Now, we're not snobby nor are we regular haters, so this review is coming from a very fair and reasonable place. 

Two of us ordered Cup of Excellence beans, and what resulted was horrific. We could not drink it without cringing. All four cups of coffee were bitter and sour....over-extracted! The barrista either used too fine of a grind and maybe even the wrong temperature. What is the point of having such quality beans and an expensive machine if one is going to f*!@ it up? We jetted out of the City, mouths puckering, frowning, and swearing off coffee indefinitely.... $15 for 4 cups of coffee, too. 

Maybe the barrista just made a mistake and maybe he makes a good cup at other times. I don't know. But I do know that I don't want to spend $5  again for a cup to find out. We should've said something then, but we were so turned off that our normal senses escaped us in the moment.
author: S. P.

description: Noe Valley in Bayview/Hunter's Point?  Well, as I walked through the high-end nursery with its exotic flora and $695 flower pots, all the while thinking of the neighborhood's socials ills, I couldn't help but experience a bit of cognitive dissonance.  No matter, the Ritual espresso drinks are up to par, even if incongruity is the name of the game in this oasis in the 'hood.
author: Paul D.

description:
Unbelievable.  And I totally thought I'd be first line to review Ritual Gardens.

The place is horrible.  Don't go there.  The coffee on Valencia Street is much better.  Trust me.
author: Hanson L.

description: Love this place. One of the best hidden gems in SF. Great coffee and fresh pastries are made even greater by having them in the jungles of Flora Grubb!
author: Michal W.

description:
don't get me wrong-I LOVE Flora Grubb. but what is up with the barista here? she is a b!tch!  I have been here many times (I work nearby) and there is one girl who is way more into her conversation with whoever is sitting at the counter, than helping me!

I worked as a barista for over a decade, I know how customers can be. but if I just walked in, how is somebody else's unpleasentness my fault? and since this has happened on more that one occasion, it can't be that she's having a bad day. (unless she's always having a bad day.)  

also, she spoke to the (customer? friend? whatever) in spanish-about me! I guess she didn't think I could understand her since I'm white. but surprise! I'm from California, stupid. of course I can understand you. 

it was beyond rude to talk about me, in front of me, in another language. I'm sorry if you hate white people or whatever, but can you do your job? or is that asking too much? 

needless to say, I won't be getting coffee here anymore. Piccino isn't that far away, I'll make the trek. they've never every been anything but nice there.
author: J R.

description:
Excellent Coffee in a Nursery filled with crazy sh**. crazy in a good way of course. I remember sitting there surrounded by exotic plants and greenery. sippin on a gibraltar reading a book about labryinths. And in my mind i was thinking "and im in the dogpatch?" 

regardless the people are cool, friendly and serve great coffee. AND i dont have to deal with the mission heads.
author: Mohammad G.

description:
I haven't tried the other spots, but why should I?  This one is nestled in a beautiful oasis, hidden from the black magic of hipster-dom and homeless wi-fi stealers.  I am one of only four people in line, at their busiest.  Yes, I agree with Toni T's review that it can be expensive, but look what you are buying!  I admit, for a single cup of drip coffee, that's too much money.  But the prices are comparable for the espresso based drinks, and they have really good espresso.  I mean, they roast their own beans, right?  That doesn't always mean good things.  
Sometimes, the coffee is strictly for aficionados.  Not for someone who wants a traditional house blend.  Strawng.  Can be "bitter" at times.  The real treat, I am embarrassed to say, was simply a Mocha.  I have had many a Mocha at many an establishment.  The lady that made this was a "drink decorator" and she made this one a masterpiece!  I don't understand how, but the whole thing, including the foam was chocolatey goodness.  Seriously.  Really really chocolatey.  The coffee and milk were really good and perfectly hot too.  It's their only flavored drink.  It's all they need.  Thanks, ritual.  Thanks a ton.
author: Joshua K.

description:
I am not an imbecile.  At home I use a Technivorm for drip, and I have a heat-exchanger for espresso.  I buy my coffee from intelligentsia.  I am not a pro, but definitely a coffee geek.  I went wayyyyyyy out of my way to go to this place.  I chose a CoE coffee to savor from their Clover.  It was the worst cup coffee I have ever had.  It was the epitome of over-extraction, extremely bitter and sour and bitter and bitter.  It got worse as it cooled.  It ruined my day and I felt like stabbing myself in the eye with a fork. 

Maybe I should be impressed that someone found a way to make the worst cup of coffee ever with an $11,000 machine, and an otherwise extremely good CoE bean.

On the positive, I like their logo, cups, saucers, and setting.  Where else can you find $2,250.00 rattan chairs?

Hopefully it was just a bad grind or something that can be easily fixed.  I will never know, because I will never go back.
author: Godzilla C.

description:
this place isn't open when i need them at 6 a.m. and there is plenty of parking. in the afternoon, parking is scarce here. the outside is schrouded in flora  since a nursery sells plants here. it's looks like this coffery has subletted a portion of this nursery.  i had no idea where the coffery was. it was like entering a corn maze and searching for the golden pot of coffee. i just listened for voices or signs of life or just followed the many paths available.

i spotted the coffery in the distant corner and i stood at the modest counter when i arrived there. i then heard a voice and noticed it came from the barrista who was sitting down on a stool in the corner. she gave me a list of coffees available from columbia, el slavador,  ethiophia, kenya, etc. 

 misty from ethiophia was my choice for it's purported  "sweetness."

each cup is individuallly grounded and brewed to ensure it's freshness. the large (3.25) was smooth and a had a sweetness tinge to it.

pros
-great coffee!  ritual is also available at 504 and rooz in oaktown according to my taste buds.
-friendly helpul service.
-walking thru the plants calmed me down from the hectic outside world.

cons
-parking nonexistent.
-do not believe it is pricey. bluebottle (12 oz)  is 2 @504, rooz about the same.
author: Victor G.

description:
YEEEEAAAAAHHHHHH! 
  Wonderful coffee without all the bullshit. Its amazing. No line. No Bullshit. No Hipster Insanity. No Line out the door. No Mac Books! 
Unbelievable. Really, Really Amazing. 
Plus the added bonus of being in a beautiful garden space once you have your coffee...
author: amy b.

description:
I came here today w. a few friends. We were at the Valencia location over the weekend and noticed their ads for the new location at the cash register. We were pretty intrigued...and being the semi-loyal Ritual patrons that we are (I say "semi" b/c yeah, we go to other coffee shops too, I mean, who doesn't?!), we kind of felt obligated to check it out asap.

Well, it was definitely different...I knew that it was supposed to be next to a garden or something (in the bayview, no less), but it was actually sort of situated in the back of an upscale garden supply store...I mean, don't get me wrong, it was a perfectly pleasant environment...I don't even really know what else to say about it, other than it was...surprising! 

Coffee was consistent with what I would expect to get on Valencia...they had pastries and breads as well, but a seemingly more limited selection...big logistical difference, though, in that we were THE ONLY ONES THERE...imagine that! I mean, after all, this is RITUAL, people!!! Well, there were other peeps shopping in the space for garden supplies, but let's just say there was no line out the door :) 

I went to their website beforehand and printed out a nifty little buy-one, get-one-free promotional drink coupon...and seeing how my bf is a little tight on some ends these days (so to speak), we just might come back with another coupon in tow, for that very reason, if nothing else!!!
author: Shannon R.

description:
So one day I was sitting at Big Ritual in the Mission and they had little tents on their table saying a new location was opening.. to my excitement having moved two weeks ago, it opened on the same street I live on! 

Not to mention the few awesome parties I've been to there, it's hands down the most beautiful cafe ever because it's practically in a rain forest. No wifi so there's not a bunch of drones spacing out all the time, and the staff is lovely. Danielle makes the best lattes and she's great to sit and chat with.
author: Stefan J.

description:
I love this place. 10 stars.

I like to garden, and I like coffee. Ritual coffee (my favorite coffee). Flora Grubb gardens (my favorite nursery). Great combo.

Atmosphere is wonderful - rare plants, beautifully arranged, you forget you are at a nursery and think you're in someone's yard.

I don't know why people are so freaked out by the baristas at Ritual. I've had great experience with everyone here - totally nice people, down to earth even, at least in my conversations with them. I will keep going back and back!
author: sam p.

description: 3 stars for the superb flora and fauna, but 2 stars off for the coffee.  The java here is very weak, to the point where I could hardly taste the coffee.  Also, the barista spends a lot of time talking and not brewing.  For a teacher who's constantly on the go, we need our coffee and we need it fast!
author: Linh D.

description:
This place keeps me happy in the middle of stressful days when I'm out in the Bayview.  Before this, there wasn't really a GREAT cup of coffee anywhere near the Bayview---and in an instant, now there is.  Yes, yes, yes, you can find a brewed cup of Peerless down there (Tiffany's in the Bayview Plaza), but this is genuinely great coffee offered up (in my experience) baristas who feel the love for the bean.
Patronize it and smile.
author: Roger W.

description:
"Mmmm" is the sound of pleasure, and sometimes a awkward "yes." After taking one sip of the Brazilian coffee recommended to me by the Barista, I managed to give both "mmm" in one gesture...pretty amazing.

The barista smiled, and so did I because I had my coffee, and well I had just made a fool of myself. Nonetheless, the coffee was nothing short but amazing.

They use a contemporary coffee machine (one I'd never seen), which is like a reverse french press with a suction mechanism at the base. Don't ask me to explain why it tastes so amazing, I'll just make an ass of myself further. 

This place isn't necessarily a "lets sit and have coffee," but if you're in the area,  maybe grabbing some plants and supplies, definitely grab a cup a coffee.

My only complaint, the cheapest cup of coffee is $2.50. Really? I guess you pay for that "mmm" in someway.

SFCritic
author: David J.

description:
OK. So I thought Blue Bottle coffee was the shit. Yesterday I was invited for a cuppa at Ritual Gardens and I saw coffee nirvana. A small counter ensconced within the Flora Grubb Gardens nursery I sat and waited for a friend. Meandering around one of the most beautiful nurseries I've ever seen, I wondered at the wide selection and the taste of the shop owner. As my friend arrived we sat at the counter on a couple of beautiful, heavy, hand-made stools. The gal behind the counter offered us a menu of six different types of beans. We made our selection and she went to work brewing our cups on the Clover device. Now, if you haven't had a cup of coffee prepared on a Clover you're in for a treat. The flavor of the fresh beans came through like I'd never experienced. (I immediately investigated one of these devices for my home but at $11K it was a bit too pricey.)

Needless to say, this was perfection for a lazy Sunday morning cup of Joe...especially if you plan to do a little gardening. I consider Ritual Gardens state of the art for SF coffee.
author: Gary C.

description:
After writing reviews for a few other Bayview locations (SCRAP and the Bayview Goodwill) I realized that my efforts actually had the reverse affect of making me want to hit up all these locations again, hence my first visit to Ritual Gardens. 

First, I had to take a piss (I get really excited to go to new places) and discovered that Flora Grubb's and Ritual Gardens might just have the nicest bathrooms in SF.  I'm not going to tell you any more because you'll just have to go and visit.

Second, if you've ever wanted to talk to the baristas at Ritual, but never had the chance because they are too f'ing busy all the time, THIS is your chance.  Danielle is sweet, sweet, sweet.  We had a lovely conversation during which time I finished my delicious coffee.  

Third, most people I talk to have not been out to Bayview because they think it is a dangerous neighborhood. As a skittish girl from the Midwest, I can attest that yes, I did feel nervous in this area back in August when is started classes at the Evans campus. After several months attending classes and discovering that everyone in this neighborhood is friendly and will stop for anything in a crosswalk, I can safely ask, what are all you thumb-suckas waiting for?
author: Lynn G.

description: This place is great for meetings with clients.  Since I'm based out of the Bayview (holla at ya girl!), our clients are generally wary of meeting me here.  Instead of getting shot at, they get fresh shots of espresso.  Oh, that pun was bad-even for me.
author: Monica L.

description:
Warm fall Saturday afternoon + Ritual Coffee + loads of awesome plants and gardening supplies (why do I not have a yard or at least a patio grrr) = another I heart San Francisco Day.
How did I just discover this awesome place behind Taco Bell?  Don't ask me how I know about Taco Bell.
author: Sarah M.

description:
By far my favorite. Absolutely hands down.

First time I went in to this location was about the time my gf and I  moved to the next block down. I was excited to have good coffee so nearby. The woman working at that time was terse and didn't seem super excited that I was interrupting her from her conversation with whomever was sitting at the bar. However, she proceeded to make me the BEST americano (I have only ever ordered tea or regular coffee when I have visited the Valencia Street location) I have EVER had. This americano was so good that I, a person who sips coffee until its cold, had finished my drink before even arriving home...a short two minute walk to the next block!
Since then I've been hooked (though I wasn't super excited about possibly running in to the unfriendly barista on my return trip). Thankfully, Ms. Unfriendly was only there one other day and since then they've had a great, friendly staff working. I'm not sure of everyone's names but they've all been great to talk to, informative about the different coffees they have and just a fun way to start my day. 

My favorite coffee served in an oasis of beautiful plants and succulents just a few hundred feet from my house....who could ask for anything more?

Amendment: Aaron and Maria and AWESOME! I just wish Flora Grubb hadn't changed its hours.
author: Jes M.

description:
I love Ritual Coffee - i have a picture of their coffee in my photos - so i was so happily surprised to see a little "caffe" at the back of the new Flora Grubb Gardens in Bayview.  

Its a mini, upscale coffee bar surrounded by the gorgeous surroundings and plants of the upscale garden center.  There are lots of choices for pastries and treats too.  There is also a park bench table if you want to sit down.  

I was there in april, before the grand opening, and it was pretty quiet.  I suppose when more people find out about it, it will get more busy.  

Its not a coffee shop where you go to hang out.  But what better reason to go plant and gardening shopping than to  get some treats at the Ritual Coffee Bar.
author: Nancy X.

description: Good coffee in the mission!  Highly recommend trying,  not four stars only because its hard to say this is necessarily better than Blue Bottle or Four Barrel...  i would try all three and pick your favorite
author: Manoj L.

description: I asked them for a half caf drip and they told me they wouldn't do half cal on the drips but they could do a half caf expresso or americano.  Very bad customer service with a bad attitude because they may have had to throw away 35 cents worth of coffee for a $3 cup of drip coffee.  Next time I will stop and get my coffee before I visit Flora Grub nursery.
author: Marlin P.

description:
Whilst riding in the hood, I stopped in here with my motorcycle gang (well, not really a gang... more like a group of guys and gals riding the same type of bike) looking to raise a ruckus while swillin' some good ol bean juice.  Our gang leader brought us here instead of the Valencia location because it was supposedly better, in his opinion.
I couldn't agree with him more! Same bean juice they serve at the Valencia Ritual, but the atmosphere is much more chill. The bean counter is tucked away inside the nursery, which I found an odd place for a coffee joint.  The gibralters there are F'n amazing.  Good stuff.
author: Ranier D.

description: Environment is great, being facilitated in the heart of Flora Grubb.  Surrounded by many plants, its really an awesome experience. but it cost so much.
author: Gurvinderpal S.

description: One of a great many reasons to venture out and visit lovely Hunters Point. As Gretchen perfectly describes it, "an oasis in the middle of the deepest urban jungle." Well said, and I'll add that the lines are much shorter here than on Valencia st, the hipsters not so hip and the coffee and espresso concoctions are just as tasty. I'd rather share my coffee with a cactus any day.
author: Phil M.

description:
You will find, tucked away amidst aisles upon aisles of the jungly plant filled Flora Grubb, a secret treasure in the form of a Ritual Coffee Roasters stand. The coffee here is the same as at the mother institution on Valencia, with the added perk of a line and crowd free atmosphere. On a sunny afternoon we happened upon this quiet coffee cart, run by a single barrista who was probably bored out of his mind and excited by the site of coffee craving customers. He happily chatted our ears off while preparing our drinks, distracting me so much that I didn't realize that I probably ordered the most expensive soy latte in the history of soy lattes. Yes, I paid a whopping $4.15 for a 10 oz serving of caffeinated bliss. The milk froth pattern I'll admit was superbly executed- far better than at Valencia's shop. My friends ordered an assortment of of other coffees, the special being a "clover" which is a special process of making coffee whereby each batch is extremely standardized in brewing temperature etc. I will overlook the sky high price and give this shop a favorable rating for three reasons. 1.) The barrista was so kind he punched 5 holes in my "heavy drinker" card which allows you a free coffee after 10 punches.
2.) We had the pleasure of drinking our over priced beverages in a charming garden setting, complete with trickling fountains and leafy palms.
3.) The bathroom is probably the 2nd nicest bathroom I've encountered in SF filled with lush plants and loads of light.
author: Kate A.

description: Are you sitting down? The best cappuccino breve I have ever consumed was born here at Ritual Coffee in Hunters Point. Lovely that the wee cafe is housed in an oasis in the middle of the deepest urban jungle, but it truly stands alone. The sweet barrista explained that the $30K machine was imported from somewhere interesting and how even the drip coffee was made by the cup and something about, "you can't rush the process," but I could not focus past the perfect rich foam and the unburnt, uncompromised coffee in my cup. Mind blowing, just go.
author: Gretchen T.

description: I had the soy cappuccino here. They know how to foam soymilk properly. I like my coffee a bit more hot though so I docked a star. The coffee was just right, not too bitter or earthy/fruity. It's fun to sip coffee while checking out all the stuff at Flora Grubb.
author: saurabh S.

description: best coffee in san fran!
author: Esra O.

description:
i love. 

if there is a place to read and plug in my laptop you best believe i am going to get some serious work done. 

my sister and i went. we live in the neighborhood. the place is lovely. perfect place to catch all the sun the bayview has to offer. definitely, golden.
author: Karla P.

description: What a wonderful treat while shopping for desert plants to stop here for a chai and a slice of gingerbread.  We also shared a cup of Ethiopian because we were enjoying the plant shopping so much we were there for hours yesterday.
author: Tracy A.

description:
get on your bike, work it, and you'll be rewarded with a great cup.
well I rewarded myself with some kick-ass 3ple capp.

ritual coffee and you can also buy a little companion plant.
amazing space and knick knacs.
(ahm-amazing for no computers YAY!)
the gravel and plant and all reminds me it should be hotter. 
grrrr fog go away

BEANS: They now roast their own. (used to be roasted by Stumptown)
author: ninja M.

description: Although I love Ritual beans, I would rather drive 15 minutes out of my way to get a Gibraltar at Ritual Gardens, than tolerate the masses of iPod'ed, wireless iMac'ed, soon to be iPhone'd, skinny jean'ed, scrappy enough to get noticed, poetry-writing, texting fools on Valencia Street!
author: Mariangela S.

description: Great coffee, this location has a very nice setting in the middle of industry. Tucked away like a delicious little secret.
author: Hank T.

description: Went to this killer space last Sunday to buy some plants. Got there as they were closing but ended up getting some beans. Ethiopia Yirgacheffe roasted to perfection. I have already gone through the whole bag. Sooo good! I will be coming back here for sure
author: Pat F.

description: These guys have what is arguably the best coffee in the city.  Nice selection, especially of lighter roasts, which can be harder to find.  Definitely worth checking out, especially if you can make it there when there isn't a giant line out the door!
author: Tod G.

description: Who knew they had a coffee shop behind all those plants at Flora Grubb? Not me because I don't drink coffee, but I they do have hot chocolate which I do drink. Not a bad hot chocolate and I liked the little design on top. Oh yeah, the Rocky Road cookies are the bomb also.
author: D J.

description:
ok so, i love ritual and used to go all the time when i lived over on fair oaks, but now i'm in bernal and it's not the 10-minute walk it once was.  plus, it can get just a bit too hipster in there for my taste--and i say this knowing full well of my own love/hate relationship with the hipster ilk, as well as that i could be mistaken for a member of said species.  (perhaps by an uneducated marina sorority girl, but mistaken nonetheless...)

anyhow, when we first learned of the ritual satellite location, we went over--and stumbled upon a paradise.  flora grubb gardens is so spectacularly gorgeous and serene, it makes drinking coffee in a loud, packed coffeehouse seem downright mad.  plus, i find it kind of funny that the baristas are friendlier here than at the valencia location; i guess they can show a bit of humanity if no one's looking...  or it could just be the fact that the flora grubb hipsters are taking care of the snarky condescension for them.  (christ, you SELL PLANTS.  that's IT.  and i don't mean that in an elitist way, i just mean IT'S JUST A FUCKING PLANT.  it's not going to alleviate world hunger or bring about peace in the middle east.)  the only thing is, there's usually only one barista working, so even is the line is only a few people deep, you're gonna have a wait.  but that's fine: browse the grounds, fall in love with the foliage, leaf through the books, gasp at the $610 bench that is made out of ONE thin sheet of metal (gasp at the price, folks, not the architecture).  it's a lovely lovely space, and i usually wander, latte in hand, for a couple of hours; indeed, the fifth and final star is for the ambiance.
author: V. m. g.

description: good place good urban hiped place gone yuppie to young and makeing it or trying to here
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.
